metadata.title: Enhanced bone tissue regeneration using a 3D printed microstructure incorporated with a hybrid nano hydrogel

sections.text:
Nanoscale rsc.li/nanoscale
ISSN 2040-3372
PAPER Lijie Grace Zhang et al. Enhanced bone tissue regeneration using a 3D printed microstructure incorporated with a hybrid nano hydrogel
Volume 9 Number 16 28 April 2017 Pages 5025–5354

sections.heading: Nanoscale
sections.text:
PAPER
Cite this: Nanoscale, 2017, 9, 5055
Received 14th December 2016, Accepted 2nd February 2017
DOI: 10.1039/c6nr09652b
rsc.li/nanoscale
Enhanced bone tissue regeneration using a 3D printed microstructure incorporated with a hybrid nano hydrogel
Dong Nyoung Heo,a Nathan J. Castro,b Se-Jun Lee,a Hanaul Noh,a Wei Zhua and Lijie Grace Zhang*a,c,d
Three-dimensional (3D) functional constructs with biomimetic mechanical and chemical properties are
ideal for various regenerative medicine applications. These properties of 3D fabricated constructs mainly
depend on the intrinsic characteristics of the materials and fabrication method. In this respect, the current
use of hydrogels for musculoskeletal tissue repair is not ideal due to the lack of suitable mechanical pro-
perties, as well as the high biomimetic requirement for success. To overcome this limitation, we develo-
ped a novel functionalized hydrogel with bioactive gold nanoparticles (GNPs), reinforcing a 3D printed
microstructure via fused deposition modeling (FDM) for bone tissue regeneration. We used biodegradable
thermoplastic polylactic acid (PLA) as the 3D printed microstructure in combination with photo-curable
gelatin hydrogels as the encapsulation matrix for the incorporation of cyclic RGD conjugated GNPs
(RGNP), and investigated their mechanical properties. In addition, human adipose-derived stem cells
(ADSCs) were encapsulated within the gelatin hydrogel and examined for viability, morphology, and
osteogenic differentiation in vitro. The results showed that the stiffness of the composite hydrogel on
reinforcing a 3D printed microstructure can be readily modulated to simulate the stiffness of the human
mandibular condyle. ADSCs encapsulated in the composite structures remained viable within the hydro-
gel and showed excellent spreading on the 3D printed PLA microstructure. More importantly, osteogenic
differentiation with incorporated RGNPs promoted significantly higher gene expression of osteogenic
specific factors. Therefore, reinforced composite hydrogels are suitable for stem cell differentiation
control and bone tissue regeneration.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Within the biomedical and biotechnological field, biodegradable hydrogels have been proven as an important class of biomaterials due to their excellent biocompatibility, biodegradability, water content, and soft mechanical properties which mimic natural tissue.1–3 Recently, there has been a great deal of research focusing on cell encapsulated hydrogels and 3D printing to engineer various tissues ranging from liver to bone.4,5 3D bioprinting of cell-laden hydrogels for the fabrication of 3D functional living tissue analogs is an effective method capable of transferring a large amount of desired cells into a damaged tissue.6,7 Many groups have developed these approaches to improve, replace or regenerate damaged/ diseased tissue, but the low mechanical properties of hydrogels remain an inherent limitation. In most systems, insufficient mechanical properties of the hydrogel compromise the structural integrity of the scaffold leading to compromised results especially in musculoskeletal tissue repair.4,8,9 In addition, the loss of cell viability during the processing of 3D bioprinting such as increased dispensing pressure, nozzle gauge and fabrication time are disadvantageous for the production of 3D functional constructs.10,11 When attempting to extrude a viscous hydrogel solution within living cells, higher compressive stresses inflicted upon the 3D printed material result in decreased cell viability. Although highly viable 3D cell-laden constructs can be fabricated using low dispensing pressure and larger nozzles, other drawbacks such as decreased structure resolution and printing speed arise.12–14
To address these shortcomings, many studies have dedicated significant efforts to develop a combination of cell-laden hydrogel with woven or non-woven thermoplastic poly-

View Article Online View Journal | View Issue
mers,15,16 nano- or microfiber meshes,17,18 and inorganic materials.19,20 The mechanical properties of composite hydrogels are enhanced and can support cell viability and function from mechanical stress during the regeneration process. However, even though hybrid/composite hydrogels are mechanically strong, several disadvantages still remain for various reasons, such as limited control over the 3D architecture,21 toxic degradation products,22 and insufficient mechanical properties compared to native bone tissue.23,24
In recent years, focus has shifted to improve bone tissue regeneration using osteo-conductive or inductive agents.25 With regard to the successful delivery system of osteogenic agents, it is necessary to retain the agent at the defective area for periods of time needed to effectively treat the defect.26 Therefore, various types of nano- and micro carriers have been used as biomolecule delivery systems.27 Amongst these, gold nanoparticles (GNPs) are very attractive materials for systemic delivery due to several inherent benefits including non-cytotoxicity, ease of preparation with defined sizes, high reproducibility, and easy surface modification with various thiol-containing biomolecules through gold–thiol bonding.28 In particular, GNPs are the most efficient carriers in the field of bone tissue regeneration because of their effects on the bone remodeling process by enhancing osteogenic differentiation while inhibiting osteoclast activity.29–34
In light of these findings, we developed a functionalized and reinforced composite hydrogel with a 3D printed microstructure and bioactive gold nanoparticles (GNPs). 3D printed microstructures with different porosities were fabricated using biodegradable thermoplastic polylactic acid (PLA) by fused deposition modeling (FDM). Cyclic peptides containing the cell-adherent arginine–glycine–aspartate (RGD) sequence were conjugated upon the surface of GNPs (RGNPs) to enhance human adipose-derived stem cell (ADSC) behavior for bone remodeling. Then, functional cell-laden hydrogels incorporated with methacrylated gelatin (GelMA) and RGNPs were combined with the PLA microstructure by infusion and UV-induced chemical crosslinking. We demonstrated that ADSCs encapsulated within the reinforced composite hydrogels can be exploited to produce biomimetic 3D structures with both high mechanical strength and osteogenic differentiation potential. Therefore, this strategy may be a useful platform for regulating stem cell functions and treating defective bone tissues.

sections.heading: 3D PLA microstructure design and fabrication
sections.text:
The 3D PLA microstructure was designed and printed based on our previously reported method.35 For embedding the hydrogel inside the 3D PLA microstructure, computer-aided design (CAD) based architectural models with the square open pore were designed with various fiber spacings from 0.6 mm to 1.4 mm, and printed using a FDM 3D printer. The 3D PLA microstructures were composed of parallel-aligned fibers
measuring 200 μm thickness at a 250 μm layer height. The CAD models of various microstructures were used to calculate their porosity.

sections.heading: Preparation and characterization of GNPs and RGNPs
sections.text:
GNPs were synthesized by the reduction of chloroauric acid with trisodium citrate as described previously.29 The GNP solution was used without further purification in all experiments. To prepare RGD-conjugated GNPs, Tween 20 solution (1 mM, 500 μl) was first added into 5 mL of GNP solution obtained from the previous step and then the mixture was stirred for 10 min. After stirring, 500 μl of RGD peptide (1 mM) was added and then reacted for 2 h to allow the chemical exchange of the citrate with thiol. The peptide-conjugated GNPs (RGNPs) were purified by centrifugation (12 000 rpm for 10 min) twice. After decanting the supernatant, the pellet was re-dispersed in distilled water. To determine the surface plasmon resonance of GNPs and RGNPs, ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) absorbance was measured using a Multiskan GO microplate spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). To determine the size of GNPs and RGNPs, atomic force microscopy (AFM) was performed using a Cypher™ AFM (Asylum Research, USA) in conventional tapping mode with an Olympus Micro Cantilever model AC160TS.
Preparation of a reinforced composite hydrogel
GelMA was synthesized by methacrylation of gelatin derived from type A porcine skin, as described previously.30 Synthesized GelMA was dissolved in Dulbecco’s phosphatebuffered saline (DPBS) containing 0.1 wt% photoinitiator (Irgacure 2959, Sigma-Aldrich) at 8 wt%. Subsequently, 1 mL of these mixed solutions were injected into the 3D PLA microstructure and exposed to UV light for 60 s (gelatin hydrogel, Gel). To compare the functionality of the GNPs and RGNPs, 1 mL of aqueous GNP and RGNP solution was centrifuged and the pellets were then added into 4 mL of the above mixture and labelled as ‘Gel–GNP’ and ‘Gel–RGNP’. All samples were incubated in DPBS at 37 °C for 24 h and used for further experiments.

sections.heading: Mechanical characterization
sections.text: For the characterization of mechanical properties, a biopsy punch was used to take cylindrical samples measuring 5 mm diameter and 2 mm height (10 layer). The compressive modulus of GelMA hydrogel, PLA scaffolds and the reinforced composite hydrogels was measured using an MTS criterion universal testing system (MTS Corporation, USA) in a single uniaxial uniform compression mode (n = 8). The samples were placed on the platen and a static force was applied at the rate of 5 mm min−1. The compressive modulus was calculated from the linear elastic region of the stress–strain curve.

sections.heading: ADSC culture
sections.text:
ADSCs (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) were cultured in MesenPRO RS™ medium composed of MesenPRO RS™ growth supplement, 2 mM glutamine, and 1% penicillin/

streptomycin (PS). The cells were cultured under standard cell culture conditions in a humidified atmosphere with 5% CO2 at 37 °C. For cellular experiments and analyses, ADSCs were harvested, collected by centrifugation at 1200 rpm for 5 min and then used at six cell passages or less. For osteogenic differentiation studies, ADSCs were cultured in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle’s Medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 1% PS, 50 μg mL−1 L-ascorbic acid, 10 mM β-glycerophosphate and 10 nM dexamethasone.

sections.heading: Cell viability assay
sections.text: Cell viability of the various scaffolds was evaluated by using a cell counting kit (CCK, Dokindo Molecular Technologies INC., Japan) assay. After seeding the cell in well plates, the cells were treated with various concentrations of RGD, GNPs and RGNPs and their optical density (OD) was measured at 450 nm by using a microplate reader. The cell viability assay was conducted at 24 and 48 h.

sections.heading: Cell adhesion and proliferation
sections.text:
To evaluate the effect of the Gel–RGNP composite hydrogels on cell adhesion, spreading and proliferation, cell-laden hydrogels were prepared by UV-induced chemical crosslinking using various kinds of hydrogel solutions with ADSCs (2 × 106 cells per ml). After encapsulating the cells, the morphologies of the attached and spread cells were examined after 24 h. The cytoskeletal organization was identified with actin staining using fluorescein (FITC)-phalloidin. The samples were rinsed three times with DPBS, fixed in 10% formalin for 60 min, permeabilized in 0.1% Triton X-100 for 30 min, and blocked with 2.5% BSA for 60 min at room temperature. Next, the samples were incubated with FITC-phalloidin for 60 min and washed three times with DPBS. The stained samples were observed and imaged using a Zeiss 710 confocal laser scanning microscope (CLSM). ImageJ (NIH Freeware) was used to quantify the total area of cell spreading within the hydrogels.36 To confirm the cell proliferation rate, cell-laden hydrogels were incubated for 1, 4, and 7 days, and quantified using the CCK assay as previously described.
Quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR)
To evaluate the osteogenic gene expression profiles of type I collagen (COL1), alkaline phosphatase (ALP), runt-related transcription factor 2 (RUNX2) and bone sialoprotein (BSP), realtime PCR was performed after 7 and 14 days of osteogenic differentiation. At each time point, the total RNA of ADSCs encapsulated with Gel, Gel–GNPs and Gel–RGNPs was isolated by using an RNeasy Plus Mini Kit (Qiagen, USA) as per the manufacturer’s instructions. The primers of the measured mRNA genes were as follows: COL1 (forward: ATG ACT ATG AGT ATG GGG AAG CA, reverse: TGG GTC CCT CTG TTA CAC TTT), ALP (forward: AGC TGA ACA GGA ACA ACG TGA, reverse: CTT CAT GGT GCC CGT GGT C), RUNX2 (forward: AAC CCA CGA ATG CAC TAT CCA, reverse: CGG ACA TAC CGA CGA GGG ACA TG), BSP (forward: AAC GAA GAA AGC GAA GCA GAA,
reverse: TCT GCC TCT GTG CTG TTG GT), and glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) (forward: ATG GGG AAG GTG AAG GTC G, reverse: GGG GTC ATT GAT GGC AAC AAT A). Real-time PCR was analyzed by using SsoFast™ EvaGreen® Supermix (Bio-Rad, USA). Threshold cycle values were calculated by using a comparative cycle threshold method. The fold change of ADSCs cultured under standard cell culture conditions was set at 1-fold and the ratio of the normalized fold change was calculated; all results were normalized by GAPDH.

sections.heading: Statistical analysis
sections.text: All values were presented as the mean ± standard deviation (SD). A one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) with Student’s t-test was used to verify statistical differences amongst the groups. The differences with p-values (*p < 0.05, **p < 0.01) were considered statistically significant.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
Fabrication of 3D-printed PLA scaffolds infilled with hydrogel and GNPs
A schematic diagram of the fabrication process of 3D PLA scaffolds infilled with hydrogel and GNPs is shown in Fig. 1. First, 3D PLA scaffolds were pre-designed with various fiber spacings from 0.6 mm to 1.4 mm and fabricated with CADbased architectural designs by FDM (Fig. 2A). The resultant scaffolds had porosities varying from 74.2% to 86.8% (Fig. 2B). All 3D PLA scaffolds had multilayers of parallel-aligned fibers with orthogonal orientation, as shown in the optical images (Fig. 2C). Prior to infilling the hybrid hydrogel into the 3D PLA scaffolds, cRGD conjugated GNPs (RGNPs) and photo-curable gelatin (GelMA) were synthesized for use as an osteo-inductive agent and incorporating material with RGNPs, respectively. For the synthesis of RGNPs, cRGD was added into the aqueous solution of GNPs, which was synthesized by citrate reduction. After addition of cRGD, the color of the solution changed from

light red to pale purple, due to the immobilization of cRGDs on the surface of GNPs. This was in good agreement with the results of UV-vis spectroscopy (Fig. 3A). The UV spectral absorption of the GNP appeared at 522 nm, due to its surface plasmon resonance band. However, the absorption peak of RGNPs shifted to the right at 549 nm. It is well known that the surface modification of GNPs with thiol-containing biomolecules is easy and well-controllable due to their strong gold–thiol bonding strength.28 Therefore, the results indicated that cRGD is well conjugated on the GNP surface, thereby increasing the size of RGNPs compared to GNPs. The mor-
phology of RGNPs was examined by atomic-force microscopy (AFM) and compared to GNPs (Fig. 3B). AFM images showed that the synthesized RGNPs have a near-spherical shape with good dispersion in the range of 20–40 nm. After the synthesis of RGNPs, the mixed solutions of GelMA and RGNPs were poured into the 3D PLA scaffolds and photo-cured by UV irradiation.
Effects of cRGD, GNPs and RGNPs on the viability of ADSCs
The cell viability at different concentrations of RGD, GNPs and RGNPs for ADSCs was evaluated by using the CCK assay at 24 and 48 h (Fig. 4). It was found that all components showed no significant cytotoxic effects up to 48 h. On the contrary, GNPs and RGNPs exhibited a slight positive effect on ADSC proliferation where the cell viability increased in a dosedependent manner after 48 h. It was reported that the surface ligand of the GNPs has an important influence on the cytotoxicity.29–31,37 In this study, we used two kinds of GNPs covered with citrate and RGD, and they showed no cytotoxicity and even more enhanced cell proliferation. Therefore, this result indicates that the prepared RGNPs could be useful as a biocompatible osteo-inductive agent.
Stiffness of 3D-printed PLA scaffolds infilled with hydrogel and GNPs
Compressive mechanical testing was carried out using a universal testing machine at a crosshead speed of 5 mm min−1. The stiffness of PLA scaffolds alone decreased from 729.5 ± 78.3 MPa for 0.6 mm fiber spacing to 303.6 ± 36.7 MPa for 1.4 mm fiber spacing (Fig. 5). After infilling with Gel and GNPs, the stiffness of the scaffolds showed no significant difference: from 791.3 ± 76.9 to 296.6 ± 17.2 MPa for PLA infilled with Gel and from 704.3 ± 151.1 to 291.5 ± 46.2 MPa for PLA infilled with Gel/GNPs. For comparative purposes, the compressive modulus data of the human mandibular bone were included, as shown in Fig. 5.38 This demonstrated that all PLA scaffolds with 1.2 mm fiber spacing (401.0 ± 29.2 MPa for PLA scaffold, 378.9 ± 27.7 MPa for PLA infilled with Gel,
Fig. 2 (A) Pre-designed 3D scaffolds and (B) their porosity. (C) Optical images of different 3D PLA scaffolds with various fiber spacings, scale bar = 500 μm.
Fig. 3 Synthesis and characterization of cRGD conjugated gold nanoparticles (RGNPs) by (A) UV spectrometer and (B) AFM.

402.0 ± 26.9 MPa for PLA infilled with Gel/GNPs) have a similar compressive modulus to the human mandibular bone (431.0 ± 217.0). In contrast to the PLA scaffolds, Gel has a relatively ultra-low compressive modulus with 7.1 ± 1.0 kPa, which is much softer and weaker than the human mandibular bone. The mechanical properties of Gel are not suitable to fabricate 3D functional human constructs with mechanical properties for the clinical restoration of hard bone tissue.9,39 Therefore, reinforcement is required to maintain their 3D shape after implantation. As confirmed by mechanical testing, 3D printed PLA scaffolds after infilling with Gel might help enhance the
mechanical properties and provide initial mechanical strength over a long period of implantation time.
ADSC spreading and proliferation after encapsulation in various hydrogel components with the 3D printed PLA structure
To verify cytoskeletal organization, spreading, and proliferation of cells, ADSCs were cultured in various hydrogel components with the 3D printed PLA structure, and determined by F-actin staining and CCK assay at different time intervals (Fig. 6). Cell spreading on the outside and inside of the ADSC encapsulated hydrogel was confirmed using optical microscopy and confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM). The cells seeded on the hydrogel surfaces had well-spread and branched morphologies, whereas the cells encapsulated in the hydrogel showed granular shapes (Fig. 6A). In addition, cell spreading morphology was noticeably different, and depended on the composition of the hydrogel component. The CLSM images shown in Fig. 6B indicate that the adhered cells on the outside of the hydrogel become more highly stretched in all specimens. Among these specimens, Gel–RGNPs showed the highest cytoskeletal spreading, large lamellar morphology and numerous stress fibres. It is well known and recognized that the cRGD peptide is an integrin-binding site, which has beneficial effects on cell adhesion, spreading, and actin-filament formation.40 Moreover, structurally cRGDs have many advantages such as high affinity for interaction with cell surface integrin and low biodegradability than linear RGDs.41 Therefore, Gel–RGNPs provided a greater positive effect on surface cell adhesion when compared to Gel and Gel–GNP groups. Also, we focused on the quantitative analyses of the
Fig. 5 Compressive modulus of 3D printed PLA scaffolds, mandible, and gelatin hydrogel. (Data of mandibular bone reproduced from ref. 38.) There are no significant differences between a PLA scaffold and PLA infilled with hydrogel and GNPs. “*” indicates significant difference of p < 0.01.
Fig. 6 The effect of altering hydrogel component with the 3D printed PLA structure on ADSC spreading and proliferation. (A) Optical images of ADSC spreading outside and inside of the hydrogel structures. (B) Actin cytoskeletal organization of representative ADSCs to exist their outside after 24 h of seeding. Scale bars = 100 μm. (C) Cell outlines of twelve representative ADSCs to exist their inside after 24 h of seeding. Scale bars = 100 μm. (D) Quantification of ADSCs spreading area of the hydrogel inside. (E) Proliferation of ADSCs cultured on the Gel, Gel–GNP, and Gel–RGNP, investigated by CCK. “*” indicates significant difference of p < 0.01.

cell spreading area to each hydrogel layer and analyses of the cell proliferation rate to investigate the effect of the RGNPs. To confirm actin filament formation and spreading of ADSCs encapsulated in various hydrogel structures, cells were stained with fluorescence labeled phalloidin (Fig. 6C). In both Gel and Gel–GNP groups, encapsulated ADSCs appeared morphologically granular even after 24 h but Gel–RGNPs seemed to induce better spreading throughout the hydrogel network. In addition, the average cell spreading area in Gel–RGNPs was two-fold higher than in Gel and Gel–GNPs under the same culture conditions (Fig. 6D). With cRGD-induced increase in the cell spreading area for Gel–RGNPs, the cell proliferation rate was significantly increased in the inside of Gel–RGNPs compared to that of Gel and Gel–GNPs (Fig. 6E). Thus, Gel–RGNPs appeared to provide a more positive effect on their structure inside to enhance actin filament formation, cell spreading, and proliferation.
Effects of ADSC encapsulated Gel–RGNP hydrogels on the osteogenic differentiation
To investigate the gene expression profiles of ADSCs encapsulated within various hydrogels during osteogenic differentiation, the mRNA expressions of COL1, RUNX2, BSP and ALP were determined by real-time PCR. COL1, which is an early stage osteogenesis marker, is present in the bone extracellular matrix and expressed at high levels during bone development.42,43 Its maximum level of mRNA expression was reached on day 7, and decreased at day 14 (Fig. 7A). Other early osteogenic transcription factors, ALP and RUNX2, displayed an increased expression level over time (Fig. 7B and C). These markers are crucial osteogenic transcription factors for the generation of a mineralized bone tissue matrix.44,45 The mRNA
expressions of the early osteogenic specific markers, COL1, ALP and RUNX2, significantly increased in the order of Gel, Gel–GNPs and Gel–RGNPs during the whole period of osteogenic differentiation. Amongst these specimens, Gel–RGNPs showed much higher expression than all other sample groups. The expression level of BSP, which is a late osteogenic specific marker, increased in all specimens over the course of time. It significantly increased in the following order: Gel < Gel–GNPs < Gel–RGNPs similar to the ALP and RUNX2 results (Fig. 7D). The highest level of BSP was observed with Gel–RGNPs at whole time period. Furthermore, the highest amount of stained calcium deposition at 21 days of culture was observed in the Gel–RGNP group (Fig. 8). Overall in osteogenic differentiation studies, it was found that Gel–RGNPs showed the highest mRNA expression of all osteogenic differentiation markers.
In summary, we found that, in order to provide suitable mechanical strength over time for long-term implantation, reinforced composite hydrogels with 3D printed microstructures provide positive effects to achieve 3D functional constructs with suitable mechanical properties when compared to hydrogel constructs alone. 3D printed microstructures provide increased stiffness with a wide range of mechanical strength including the human mandibular condyle (Fig. 5). Also, embedding RGNPs into reinforced hydrogels leads to further enhanced biological effects. Before cell encapsulation into the hydrogel, cell viability tests confirmed that all components had no significant toxicity in vitro (Fig. 4). Moreover, although here we did not examine the in vivo toxicity of GNPs, previous studies have shown that GNPs do not cause any biological toxicity after in vivo injection.46,47 Therefore, GNPs are suitable materials for use as a biocompatible osteo-inductive agent. At the cellular level, RGD can be useful as a critical regulator of a cell adhesive response. Previous reports have shown that RGD
Fig. 7 Gene expression levels of ADSCs culture in the Gel, Gel–GNP, and Gel–RGNP at 7 and 14 days for osteogenic differentiation markers: (A) COL1, (B) ALP, (C) RUNX2, and (D) BSP. Relative gene expression of each gene (mean ± SD), normalized to the expression of the housekeeping gene GAPDH, are compared with ADSCs cultured in standard cell culture conditions. “*” indicates significant difference of p < 0.05. “**” indicates significant difference of p < 0.01.

enhances the attachment of numerous cell types on different types of biomaterials.48–50 As shown in a cell study, the Gel– GNP group did not show any effect on cell spreading within a hydrogel layer as compared to the Gel group. In contrast, when cells were encapsulated with Gel–RGNPs, a very high rate of cell spreading and proliferation was observed (Fig. 6). As a result, increasing cell adhesion, spreading and proliferation in Gel–RGNPs will promote the osteogenic differentiation of ADSCs under osteogenic culture conditions (Fig. 7 and 8). Interestingly, Gel–GNPs showed an enhanced osteogenic differentiation without significant difference in cell spreading and proliferation rate. These results were attributed to the incorporated GNPs, which can be used as osteogenic promoters in vitro and in vivo.30 Taken together, our composite constructs with biomechanical and biomimetic properties served two main advantages of this approach: to provide a strength reinforced microstructure and enhanced cell behavior, including cell attachment, spreading, proliferation and osteogenic differentiation. When attempting to fabricate 3D cell-laden hydrogel, it is hard for only the hydrogels to maintain their 3D shape due to the process of surgical operation and other handling factors.51–54 In these cases, our approach to overcome the weak mechanical strength of the hydrogel can eliminate its limitation for hard tissue regeneration as tissue scaffolds by reinforcement via a 3D printed microstructure.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: In conclusion, we have successfully designed and developed novel functional hydrogel incorporating RGNPs, which reinforced the mechanical strength through a combination of a 3D printed microstructure and a hydrogel. The stiffness of the composite microstructure was significantly increased to a similar level of native bone tissue. Stem cell viability tests suggest that all components had no significant cytotoxic effects while RGNPs showed a dose-dependent cell proliferation manner. Moreover, the addition of RGD to the composite constructs enhanced the cellular behavior. The in vitro experiments showed that encapsulated ADSCs in the Gel–RGNPs promoted significantly higher cell adhesion, spreading and proliferation, which led to an increased gene expression of osteogenic specific markers. Our findings suggest that reinforced composite hydrogels can be a useful strategy for improving bone tissue regeneration.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work was supported by NIH Director’s New Innovator Award 1DP2EB020549-01.
